subject: AI
title: Designing for Uncertainty
description: UX patterns for outputs that might be wrong.

hook.text: Traditional software: click 'Calculate Total' ‚Üí get the exact total. AI software: ask 'What's my total?' ‚Üí get an answer that's probably right. Designing for 'probably' is different.

buildup.text: UX patterns for uncertainty: show confidence indicators, present multiple options instead of one answer, make it easy to verify and correct, always provide a non-AI fallback.

discovery.text: Email autocomplete is a great model: suggest text, let the user accept or reject with one keystroke. The AI proposes, the human disposes. Low friction, high control.

twist.text: Users lose trust faster than they gain it. One confident wrong answer damages trust more than ten 'I'm not sure' responses. Design for appropriate confidence levels.

climax.text: The best AI UX makes mistakes recoverable: undo buttons, edit options, 'try again' prompts. Users forgive mistakes they can easily fix.

punchline.text: Design for 'probably right.' Make it easy to verify, easy to correct, easy to try again.

quiz.question: What's a key UX principle for AI features that might produce wrong outputs?
options: Never show the AI output to users
Make mistakes easy to verify, correct, and recover from
Assume the AI is always correct
